Rules

General:

1) This is a game. Play for fun. Don't be rude to other players.

2) Play to win, but also to have fun. See rule 1.

3) I will post in red. No one else is to use red.

4) Do not quote any private communications with me or other players. Failure to adhere to this rule will result in a modkill or a forced-replacement. If you have a question about whether something is acceptable, PM me.

5) You may not talk about this game outside the thread unless your role allows. When a player is killed, with the exception of a modkill, they will be given a link to a “green room.” In this room, you may chose to keep playing and discussing with other deceased players. If you have a partner/partners, do not disclose their name(s). This thread WILL be posted in post game.

6) Do not edit or delete your posts. You WILL be modkilled.

7) Posting in twilight is acceptable, for both the lynchee and all alive town members. Feel free to post as much or as little as you want of whatever you like.

8) Once your death scene is posted, you may not talk. No ‘Bah’ post, or someone on your team will be punished for your screw-up.

9) If you fake breaking a rule, it will incur the same punishment as actually breaking the rule.

10) If you believe I have made a small mistake, for example, in a vote count, please point it out in thread. If you have a more serious grievance for some reason, PM me. Leave it out of the thread.

11) My word is final.

13) I reserve the right to add rules if necessary.

Activity:

14) I expect everyone to post every 24 hours (weekends are considered only 24hrs total). Failure to do so will result in an activity prod. I will prod and if there is no post within 12 hours of prod, you will be replaced. More than two prods in the same game day will result in a modkill or a forced replacement, in which I have sole discretion in picking the limit or consequence.

15) I will take exactly 24 hours to find a replacement. If you decide to replace out, please find your own replacee. If, after the 24 hours is up, I will modkill the slot for stagnation (from initial inactivity to this point is exactly 1/2 game day), and the player may not join any more quick games I may mod.

Voting/Deadline:

14) To vote. Please vote in bold as such. vote: playerA. You do not have to unvote to vote again. You may vote for a no lynch. For voting accuracy, I ask that you place your vote at the beginning or the end of your post (this is not mandatory, but it would be appreciated).

15) Deadline will be exactly 5 days from the death scene, every day.

16) At deadline, majority is cut in half (D1 deadline would be 8 players / 2 = 4 players = 3 to lynch. If there is a tie, the player with the most votes first, will be lynched.

Town Win Condition:

You win when all other factions are eliminated and at least one person in your faction is alive, or nothing can prevent the same.

The day will start now.



Deadline for D1 is:

Well, I voted Yos because he made a very contrived case--but I'm sure he was perfectly aware that it was a contrived case even as he made it, and expected some sort of reaction to it, because I know Yos to be a rational and thoughtful player who's always aware of the information saturation levels of the game and knows reasonably well the appropriate actions to be made. In that sense my reaction to Yos' case was purely mechanical: I followed his lead in manufacturing information by attacking his flimsy case. Note that my parallel case on Epsilon is similarly flimsy.

In contrast, SleepyKrew's interrogation of Beck based on his lack of random voting rationale would only make sense in a simplistic view of game states, which he exhibited of having surpassed on some levels. He implies later, when I badger him about RVS theory, that he's aware that RVS itself a fluid progression of information saturation, which in turn implies that he's aware that to begin with, there was nothing for Beck to base his vote on. In post 375, Herodotus wrote:The town EV was at minimum 1/3, based on a D1 massclaim or massclaim of confirmable roles. For an 8 player game, and assuming this isn't ideal play, that should be within tolerance. Though making the game open would have been better.

In the event of a D-1 mass claim, we see one of two likely events:

(a) Both scum claim VT; EA claims vig and we believe him. All this accomplishes is clearing EA to reduce our pool of lynch candidates.
(b) One scum claims cop (with the intent of drawing a counterclaim from real cop). Since there is no other cop, we believe him and this player will eventually win (as he can fake investigation results to "confirm" his role).

Neither case improves town odds enough to make it a close game. Best case scenario is (a), but even in that case our odds of killing a scum before MYLO are only about 57% (2/7 on Day 1, 2/5 on Day 2). If the vig tries a kill on Night 2, he has a 2/5 chance of hitting a scum, which -- again, in the best case scenario -- which means we could survive a mislynch and this brings our total odds of killing a scum before LYLO to 74%. Sounds pretty good, right? Except this only brings us to a 3-person LYLO, with its corresponding 33% chance of victory. This equals a total odds of town victory to a meager 24%.

And that is in the best case scenario. If scum claim cop, or if vig is NK'd before Night 2 (or tries to kill on Night 1), our odds of victory are functionally nil. Furthermore, I don't think an EV of 33% is within tolerance -- 40% is about as low as a GM should go for either faction.

In post 377, Ironhead wrote:This equals a total odds of town victory to a meager 24%.

Town wins:
2/7 * 1/6(vig hits)
2/7 * 5/6(vig misses) * (1/5 + 4/5 * 1/3)
5/7 * 2/6(vig hits) * (1/5 + 4/5 * 1/3)
5/7 * 4/6(vig misses) * 2/5 * 1/3
Sum = 1/3

In post 377, Ironhead wrote:Furthermore, I don't think an EV of 33% is within tolerance -- 40% is about as low as a GM should go for either faction.
This is a valid point of view, but:
(a) There are no rules that define minimum and maximum EV, even for Normal games. This setup was clearly neither breakable nor nearly-unwinnable for either side.
(b) If we did have such rules, it would generally be difficult to evaluate EV's anyways. For this calculation, I had to make some assumptions, such as the vig claiming Day 1, which makes me think the real EV would probably be slightly higher (though still less than 40%, certainly), and the scum killing the vig on Night 1. Most setups are more complicated, mostly because there are a variety of strategies that town PR's can employ and ways that towns can respond to PR claims.

In post 378, Cogito Ergo Sum wrote:

That's not true. Town is supposed to outperform its ev. I personally think 40% is about what you should aim for in a normal 9p.

I've never seen a Mafia community wherein the town regularly outperforms EV. From what I've seen, EV is pretty accurate over the long run and variations are far more attributable to superior players stacked on one side or the other. The idea that town outperforms EV is frequently the argument of those cite town for poor scumhunting after a town-loss -- the point of view that victory or defeat is derivative of town effort, as if scum are passive in the game. But they aren't; beyond their obvious NK capabilities, they are part of the town during the day and get an equal vote in directing the lynch. In short, scum get 100% of the say in who they NK; but town does not get 100% of the say in who they lynch. EV is based on randomness, as if town were just rolling the dice to see who they lynch; when in fact, the lynch is based on the flawed voting behavior of uninformed townies and the manipulations of informed scum. Even astute scumhunting struggles to overcome these manipulations.
